On this page

Error Handling ​

Version: 0.1.2 Last Updated: November 2025

This document describes Vex's error handling system, including the Result<T, E> and Option<T> types, pattern matching for error handling, and best practices.

Table of Contents ​

  1. Overview
  2. Option<T> Type
  3. Result<T, E> Type
  4. Pattern Matching for Errors
  5. Error Propagation
  6. Custom Error Types
  7. Best Practices

Overview ​

Vex provides two primary types for handling potential failure:

  • Option<T>: Represents a value that may or may not exist
  • Result<T, E>: Represents either success (T) or failure (E)

Both types encourage explicit handling of potential errors rather than exceptions or null pointers.

Option<T> Type ​

The Option<T> type represents an optional value. It has two variants:

rust
enum Option<T> {
    Some(T),
    None
}

Basic Usage ​

rust
// Function that may not find a value
fn find_user(id: i32): Option<User> {
    if id == 42 {
        return Some(User { id: 42, name: "Alice" });
    }
    return None;
}

// Using the result
let user = find_user(42);
match user {
    Some(u) => println("Found user: {}", u.name),
    None => println("User not found")
}

Common Methods ​

rust
let maybe_value: Option<i32> = Some(42);

// Check if value exists
if maybe_value.is_some() {
    println("Value exists");
}

// Get value with default
let value = maybe_value.unwrap_or(0); // Returns 42

// Transform option
let doubled = maybe_value.map(|x| x * 2); // Some(84)

// Chain operations
let result = maybe_value
    .filter(|x| x > 40)
    .map(|x| x + 1); // Some(43)

Result<T, E> Type ​

The Result<T, E> type represents either success or failure. It has two variants:

rust
enum Result<T, E> {
    Ok(T),
    Err(E)
}

Basic Usage ​

rust
// Function that may fail
fn divide(a: i32, b: i32): Result<i32, String> {
    if b == 0 {
        return Err("Division by zero".to_string());
    }
    return Ok(a / b);
}

// Using the result
let result = divide(10, 2);
match result {
    Ok(value) => println("Result: {}", value),
    Err(error) => println("Error: {}", error)
}

Common Methods ​

rust
let result: Result<i32, String> = Ok(42);

// Check result type
if result.is_ok() {
    println("Success!");
}

// Get values
let value = result?; // Panics if Err
let value_or_default = result.unwrap_or(0);

// Transform results
let doubled = result.map(|x| x * 2); // Ok(84)

// Handle errors
let error_message = result.unwrap_err(); // Panics if Ok

// Convert Option to Result
let option: Option<i32> = Some(42);
let result = option.ok_or("Value not found"); // Ok(42)

Pattern Matching for Errors ​

Pattern matching provides elegant error handling:

rust
fn process_data(data: Vec<i32>): Result<String, String> {
    // Validate input
    if data.is_empty() {
        return Err("No data provided".to_string());
    }

    // Process each item
    for item in data {
        match validate_item(item) {
            Ok(processed) => println("Processed: {}", processed),
            Err(error) => return Err(format("Validation failed: {}", error))
        }
    }

    Ok("All data processed successfully".to_string())
}

fn validate_item(item: i32): Result<i32, String> {
    if item < 0 {
        Err("Negative values not allowed".to_string())
    } else if item > 100 {
        Err("Values too large".to_string())
    } else {
        Ok(item * 2)
    }
}

Nested Matching ​

rust
fn complex_operation(): Result<i32, String> {
    let config = load_config()?;
    let data = fetch_data(config)?;
    let result = process_data(data)?;

    Ok(result)
}

// Equivalent to:
fn complex_operation_manual(): Result<i32, String> {
    match load_config() {
        Ok(config) => match fetch_data(config) {
            Ok(data) => match process_data(data) {
                Ok(result) => Ok(result),
                Err(e) => Err(e)
            },
            Err(e) => Err(e)
        },
        Err(e) => Err(e)
    }
}

Unwrap Operator ​

Vex uses the ? operator for concise unwrapping of Result and Option types. This operator will panic if the value is an error or none.

Implementation Status: ✅ UPDATED (v0.1.2)

The ? Operator ​

The question mark operator (?) unwraps the value or panics:

rust
fn divide(a: i32, b: i32): Result<i32, string> {
    if b == 0 {
        return Err("Division by zero");
    }
    return Ok(a / b);
}

fn main() {
    let result = divide(10, 2)?;  // Returns 5
    let crash = divide(10, 0)?;   // Panics with "Division by zero"
}

How it works:

The ? operator desugars to a match expression that panics on error:

rust
// This code:
let result = divide(10, 2)?;

// Becomes:
let result = match divide(10, 2) {
    Ok(v) => v,
    Err(e) => panic(e)
};

Nested Unwrapping ​

rust
fn process_file(filename: string) {
    let content = read_file(filename)?;      // Panics if file error
    let data = parse_json(content)?;         // Panics if parse error
    let result = validate_data(data)?;       // Panics if validation error

    println(result);
}

Implementation Details:

  • Parser: vex-parser/src/parser/operators.rs - Parses expr? syntax
  • AST: vex-ast/src/lib.rs - Expression::QuestionMark(Box<Expression>)
  • Codegen: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/expressions/mod.rs - Desugars to Panic match
  • Test file: examples/test_question_mark.vx

Early Returns ​

rust
fn authenticate_user(username: String, password: String): Result<User, AuthError> {
    // Validate input
    if username.is_empty() {
        return Err(AuthError.InvalidUsername);
    }

    if password.is_empty() {
        return Err(AuthError.InvalidPassword);
    }

    // Attempt authentication
    let user = find_user(username)?;
    verify_password(user, password)?;

    Ok(user)
}

Error Rescue Operator (!>) ✅ NEW ​

The Error Rescue operator provides inline error handling without disrupting the visual flow of the "happy path". It is the semantic counterpart to ?? (Null Coalesce) but for errors rather than nil.

Full Specification: See Error_rescue_operator.spec.md

Basic Syntax ​

rust
// Form A: Inline closure
let result = risky_operation() !> |e| fallback_value;

// Form B: Direct function
let result = risky_operation() !> handle_error;

Examples ​

rust
// Provide default on error
let data = parse_json(text) !> |e| default_data();

// Log and return default
let config = load_config() !> |e| {
    log_error(e);
    return default_config();
};

// Chain with other operators
let value = fetch_data(url) !> |e| cached_data ?? default;

Comparison with Other Operators ​

OperatorPurposeUse Case
?Unwrap or panicPropagate errors up
??Default if nilHandle absent values
!>Handle error with fallbackRecover from errors inline

How It Works ​

rust
// This code:
let value = risky_op() !> |e| default;

// Desugars to:
let value = match risky_op() {
    Ok(v) => v,
    Err(e) => default
};

Custom Error Types ​

Define custom error types using enums:

rust
enum DatabaseError {
    ConnectionFailed(String),
    QueryFailed(String),
    NotFound(i32)
}

enum ApiError {
    NetworkError(String),
    AuthenticationFailed,
    ValidationError(Vec<String>),
    DatabaseError(DatabaseError)
}

fn fetch_user(id: i32): Result<User, ApiError> {
    // Attempt database connection
    let connection = connect_to_db().map_err(|e| ApiError.DatabaseError(e))?;

    // Execute query
    match connection.query_user(id) {
        Ok(user) => Ok(user),
        Err(DatabaseError.NotFound(_)) => Err(ApiError.NotFound),
        Err(e) => Err(ApiError.DatabaseError(e))
    }
}

Error Contracts ​

Implement common error contracts for better ergonomics:

rust
contract Error {
    fn message(&self): String;
}

impl Error for DatabaseError {
    fn message(&self): String {
        match self {
            ConnectionFailed(msg) => format("Connection failed: {}", msg),
            QueryFailed(msg) => format("Query failed: {}", msg),
            NotFound(id) => format("User {} not found", id)
        }
    }
}

Best Practices ​

1. Use Result for Operations That Can Fail ​

rust
// Good: Explicit error handling
fn parse_number(input: String): Result<i32, ParseError> {
    // Implementation
}

// Bad: Using Option when you need error details
fn parse_number_bad(input: String): Option<i32> {
    // Can't provide specific error information
}

2. Define Specific Error Types ​

rust
// Good: Specific errors
enum ConfigError {
    FileNotFound(String),
    ParseError(String),
    ValidationError(Vec<String>)
}

// Bad: Generic string errors
fn load_config(): Result<Config, String> {
    // Error details lost in generic strings
}

3. Use ? for Early Returns ​

rust
// Good: Clear control flow
fn process_request(req: Request): Result<Response, Error> {
    let user = authenticate(req)?;
    let data = validate_input(req)?;
    let result = perform_business_logic(user, data)?;

    Ok(create_response(result))
}

4. Handle Errors at Appropriate Levels ​

rust
// Good: Handle errors where you can respond appropriately
fn handle_request(req: Request): Response {
    match process_request(req) {
        Ok(data) => Response.success(data),
        Err(Error.ValidationError(fields)) => Response.bad_request(fields),
        Err(Error.NotFound) => Response.not_found(),
        Err(_) => Response.internal_error()
    }
}

5. Avoid unwrap() in Production ​

rust
// Bad: Will panic in production
let value = result.unwrap();

// Good: Handle the error
let value = match result {
    Ok(v) => v,
    Err(e) => return Err(e) // or provide default
};

6. Use expect() for Programming Errors ​

rust
// Good: Document assumptions
let config = loadConfig().expect("Config file should always exist");

// Bad: Silent unwrap
let config = loadConfig().unwrap();

errors Standard Library Module ​

The errors module provides advanced error handling beyond basic Result<T, E>.

Error Contract ​

rust
// Base error contract - all error types implement this
contract Error {
    fn message(self): string;
    fn cause(self): Option<&Error>;
}

Core Types ​

rust
// Standard error with optional wrapped cause
struct StdError {
    msg: string,
    cause: Option<Box<Error>>,
}

// Sentinel error for comparison
struct SentinelError {
    msg: string,
}

Constructor Functions ​

FunctionSignatureDescription
newfn new(msg: string): StdErrorCreate simple error
wrapfn wrap(err: Error, msg: string): StdErrorWrap error with context
wrapffn wrapf(err: Error, template: string, ...args): StdErrorWrap with formatted message
formatfn format(template: string, ...args): StdErrorCreate formatted error
rust
import { new, wrap, wrapf } from "errors";

// Simple error
let err = new("connection failed");

// Wrap with context
let wrapped = wrap(ioError, "failed to read config");

// Wrap with formatting
let detailed = wrapf(dbError, "query failed for user {}", userId);

Error Inspection Functions ​

FunctionSignatureDescription
isfn is(err: Error, target: Error): boolCheck if chain contains target
asfn as<T: Error>(err: Error): Option<T>Extract typed error from chain
unwrapfn unwrap(err: Error): Option<Error>Get wrapped error (one level)
chainfn chain(err: Error): stringGet full error chain as string
rust
import { is, as, chain, ErrNotFound } from "errors";

// Check for sentinel error
if is(err, ErrNotFound) {
    // Handle not found case
}

// Extract specific error type
if let Some(ve) = as<ValidationError>(err) {
    println(f"Field: {ve.field}");
}

// Print full error chain
println(chain(err));
// Output:
// failed to load config
//   caused by: file not found: config.toml

Sentinel Errors ​

Pre-defined comparable error values:

ConstantDescription
ErrNotFoundResource not found
ErrPermissionPermission denied
ErrTimeoutOperation timed out
ErrCanceledOperation canceled
ErrClosedResource closed
ErrEOFEnd of file
rust
import { ErrNotFound, ErrTimeout, is } from "errors";

fn handleError(err: Error) {
    if is(err, ErrNotFound) {
        println("Resource not found");
    } elif is(err, ErrTimeout) {
        println("Operation timed out");
    }
}

Result Extension Methods ​

rust
impl<T, E: Error> Result<T, E> {
    // Wrap error with context message
    fn wrapErr(self, msg: string): Result<T, StdError>;

    // Wrap error with formatted message
    fn wrapErrf(self, template: string, ...args): Result<T, StdError>;
}
rust
fn loadUser(id: i32): Result<User, Error> {
    let config = fs.read("config.toml")
        .wrapErr("failed to read config")?;

    let user = db.query(f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = {id}")
        .wrapErrf("failed to load user {}", id)?;

    return Ok(user);
}

Custom Error Types ​

rust
struct ValidationError {
    field: string,
    reason: string,
}

impl Error for ValidationError {
    fn message(self): string {
        return f"validation failed: {self.field} - {self.reason}";
    }

    fn cause(self): Option<&Error> {
        return None;
    }
}

fn validate(input: Input): Result<Input, ValidationError> {
    if input.email.isEmpty() {
        return Err(ValidationError {
            field: "email",
            reason: "cannot be empty"
        });
    }
    return Ok(input);
}
